metadata.title: Mixed convective non-linear radiative flowwith TiO2-Cu-water hybrid nanomaterials and induced magnetic field

sections.text:
Keywords Lorentz force, Stagnation point flow, Non-linear thermal radiation, Hybrid nanofluid, Heat generation
Paper type Research paper
Nomenclature u, v = Velocity components; H1, H2 = Magnetic components; V = Nanofluid velocity;
International Journal of Numerical Methods for Heat & Fluid Flow Vol. 29 No. 8, 2019 pp. 2754-2774 © EmeraldPublishingLimited 0961-5539 DOI 10.1108/HFF-12-2018-0748
Ue = Free stream velocity; Uw = Stretching velocity; TW =Wall temperature; T1 = Ambient temperature; Q0 = Heat generation/absorption coefficient; Pr = Prandtl number; b =Magnetic parameter; l =Mixed convection parameter; Gr = Grashof number; b 1 = Heat source/sink parameter; R = Radiation parameter; and u w = Temperature ratio parameter.
Subscript f = fluid; s = solid; r = Density; m = Dynamic viscosity; a = Thermal diffusivity; cp = Specific heat; k = Thermal conductivity; k* = Mean absorption coefficient; s* = Stefan-Boltzmann constant; tw = Shear stress; qw = Heat flux; Cfx = Skin friction coefficient; Nux = Nusselt number; Rex = Local Reynolds number; l 1 = Reciprocal magnetic Prandtl parameter; f 2 = Volumetric friction; A = Stretching parameter; nf = nanofluid; and hnf = Hybrid nanofluid.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The conventional materials like ethylene glycol, oils, water, etc., having lower conductivity are less impressive in heat conveying phenomenon. Thermal conductivity and heat transfer coefficient of base materials can be enhanced through the insertion of nanoparticles (Choi and Eastman, 1995; Buongiorno, 2006). The composition of solid particles containing 1-100 nm size in base materials are known as nanofluids. Such approach rises heat transportation in engineering utilization for illustration electronic mechanisms chilling equipped with nanofluids, food processing, energy stowing structures, heat exchangers and lubrication equipment. Choi and Eastman (1995) experimentally evaluated nanoliquids and discussed their contribution in base material along thermal conductivity improvement of the working material. Measuring thermal conductivity of ethylene glycol fluid through copper nano-particles was examined by Eastman et al. (2001). Impact of thermal radiation on magnetic nanofluid heat transfer into a curved cavity by CVFEM numerical method was studied by Sheikholeslami and Ganji (2017). Some investigations about nanofluids theory under various aspects are discussed in Qayyum et al. (2017), Pandey and Kumar (2017),
Mixed convective non-linear radiative flow
2755
Mahanthesh et al. (2016), Yin et al. (2017), Sheikholeslami et al. (2015), Hayat et al. (2017), Zhang et al. (2015), Mustafa et al. (2015), Hayat et al. (2013), Ellahi et al. (2015), Hayat et al. (2018), Sheikholeslami et al. (2016) and Sheikholeslami and Ganji (2017).
Various studies have been elaborated about nanomaterials until now, but hybrid nanoliquid is a new type of fluids, which is of great interest to the present investigation. Hybrid nanofluid is the composite of two or more constituent at nanoparticles level within a base fluid and are used to improve the heat transfer features. Suresh et al. (2012) discussed the impact of laminar convective heat transfer in the tube using Al2O3-Cu/water hybrid nanofluid. Here the improvement of gradient of temperature of hybrid nanoliquids compared to base fluid was noticed. Impact of turbulent convective heat transfer using Al2O3-Cu/water hybrid in circular tube was studied by Suresh et al. (2014). Here, we observed that heat transfer of hybrid nanofluids is 8.02 per cent enhanced than that of water-based fluid. Nasrin and Alim (2014) discussed thermal effects of applications of (alumina and copper) double nanoparticles and (alumina) single nano-particle in the waterbased fluid for forced convection by a flat plate solar collector. Their result proved that double nanoparticles had better activity than a single nanoparticle. Rostamian et al. (2017) experimentally showed that the impact of solid volume fraction changes temperature and thermal conductivity of CuO – SWCNTs – EG water. They observed that temperature and solid volume fraction have direct relation with thermal conductivity. Convective flow of silver and copper water nanofluids with thermal radiation is discussed by Hayat et al. (2016). Peristaltic flow of viscoelastic nanoparticle with Hall and ion effects is examined by Hayat et al. (2016). Shao et al. (2017) examined solidification behaviors of hybrid nanofluids containing TiNTs and TiNPs in 10 freeze-melt cycles. The obtained results are also compared to the results ofTiNT andTiNP nanofluids.
Recently many researchers have studied flow of viscous and non-Newtonian fluids under the influence of magnetic field. It is because of their numerous applications in medical industry. Alfvén (1942) indicated the study of magnetohydrodynamic (MHD). Entropy generation in Sisko fluid flow with non-linear thermal radiation and dissipation is presented by Hayat et al. (2018). Turkyilmazoglu (2018) discussed flow of nanomaterial by using Buongiorno model. Ali et al. (2011) examined the effects of induced magnetic field on MHD boundary layer flow of viscous fluid. Turkyilmazoglu (2017) scrutinized unsteady stagnation point flow of MHD viscous fluid. Kumar and Singh (2013) presented the influence of induced magnetic field on the unsteady hydromagnetic free convection over a semi-finite vertical wall. Impacts of MHD and slip velocity on the stagnation point flow of Jeffrey fluid is discussed by Turkyilmazoglu (2016). Pal and Mandal (2015) explored the impact of thermal radiation on mixed convective boundary layer stagnation point flow towards a stretching surface in porous medium. Some resent results about nanoliquids are presented in Mansor and Zaimi (2014), Mabood and Khan (2014), Hayat et al. (2018), Imtiaz et al. (2017), Khan et al. (2017), Qayyum et al. (2018) and Hayat et al. (2017).
Having above view in mind, basic focus of current attempt is to explore non-linear stretched flow of hybrid nanofluid (TiO2 – Cu/water) in four dimensions: First, to model the analysis for induced magnetic field at (TiO2 – Cu/water) nanofluid; second, to study the thermophysical features of hybrid nanofluid for various values of shape factor; third, to address the characteristics of hybrid nanofluid in the region of mixed convective stagnation point; heat transport features are explored through thermal radiation and heat generation/ absorption; and fourth, to construct the series solutions via homotopy analysis method (HAM). Some recent developments in flow of viscous and non-Newtonian materials are listed in Hayat et al. (2016), Hayat et al. (2016), Hsiao (2016), Hayat et al. (2016), Khan et al. (2017), Hsiao (2017), Hayat et al. (2018), Ahmad et al. (2018), Hsiao (2017), Qayyum et al.
HFF 29,8
2756
(2018), Khan et al. (2018), Hsiao (2017), Khan et al. (2018), Hayat et al. (2018), Turkyilmazoglu (2018), Hayat et al. (2018), Khan et al. (2017), Turkyilmazoglu (2017), Alsaedi et al. (2017) and Hayat et al. (2018). Effect of different physical parameters on the gradient of velocity, induced magnetic field and temperature are analyzed and discussed through graph. Numerical values of skin friction coefficient and gradient of temperature are tabulated and discussed via various physical parameters.

sections.heading: 2. Mathematical formulation
sections.text:
Here, mixed convective stagnation point flow of an incompressible towards a horizontal stretching surface at y = 0 is addressed. Impact of induced magnetic field and non-linear thermal radiation are considered. In Figure 1, the x-axis is along the stretching sheet and yaxis normal to it.
We know thatUe = ax andUw = cx denote the free stream and stretching sheet velocities, respectively, (a and c are the constants (a and c > 0)). Here, H is induced magnetic field and He= xH0.H0 is uniformmagnetic field. Relevant expressions are (Qayyum et al., 2018):

sections.heading: 5. Convergence
sections.text: Convergence of homotopy analysis method depends upon the auxiliary variables ħf, ħg and ħu . These parameters have important role to set up the convergence domain. Here, we have sketched the ħ – curves for the acceptable range of auxiliary parameters in Figure 2. Clearly, the suitable ranges of momentum and energy equations are –0.2 # ħf # –0.1, –0.3 # ħg # 0.01 and 0.01 # ħu # 0.0.7. Different order of approximations via different physical parameters are presented in Table III. From this, we observed that 10th, 15th and 20th order of approximations are appropriate for series solutions of momentum, induced magnetic field and temperature, respectively.

sections.heading: 6. Discussion
sections.text:
Here, velocity, induced magnetic field, temperature, surface drag force and Nusselt number are graphically discussed for the influential variables. Comparison of hybrid nanofluid and nanofluid are illustrated through graphs and tables. Here, we used the composition of
Order of approximations f 0 0 (0) g 0 (0) u (0) 1 0.00341 0.05005 0.9929 4 0.00352 0.00505 0.9981 10 0.00389 0.00405 0.9981 14 0.00399 0.00415 0.9981 15 0.00199 0.00405 0.9981 18 0.00199 0.00405 0.9981 20 0.00110 0.00404 0.9981 23 0.00110 0.00404 0.9990 25 0.00110 0.00404 0.9990 30 0.00110 0.00404 0.9990 35 0.00110 0.00404 0.9990
Cu-water and TiO2-Cu-water as nanofluid and hybrid nanofluid, respectively. Figures 3-10 disclosed the behaviors of different variables on velocity and induced magnetic field (f'(z ) and g’(z )). In these graphs, the solid lines indicate the characteristics of nanomaterials and dotted lines show the characteristics of hybrid nanomaterials. Effect of (A) on velocity and induced magnetic field (f'(z ) and g'(z )) are plotted in Figures 3-4. Here, we observed two different types of characteristics for different value of (A); a) when A< 1, that is, (Ue < Uw), then the outcome of velocity and induced magnetic field for nanoliquid is less than hybrid nanoliquid. b) When A > 1, that is, (Ue > Uw), then the value of velocity and induced magnetic field for nanoliquid is greater than hybrid nanoliquid. Moreover, no boundary layer exists for A = 0. Impact of volumetric fractions (f 2) (in nanoliquids and hybrid
Figure 6. f' (z ) via f 2
Figure 5. f' (z ) via f 2
Figure 4. g' (z ) via A
Figure 3. f' (z ) via A
HFF 29,8
2762
nanoliquids) on velocity and induced magnetic field ((f'(z ) and g'(z )) are sketched in
Figures 5-6. For A < 1, the velocity and induced magnetic field (f'(z ) and g'(z )) decay with higher estimation of volumetric friction (f 2) for both nanoliquids and hybrid nanoliquids. When A > 1, the velocity and induced magnetic field (f'(z ) and g'(z )) are enhanced with volumetric fractions (f 2). Figures 7-8 sketched the behavior of magnetic parameter b on f'(z ) and g'(z ). From these figures, it is observed that f'(z ) and g' (z ) decay via large estimations of b for A < 1 and also for A > 1. Lorentz force is a resistive force which is caused by magnetic field and a retarding force in fluid flow. When magnetic field is applied, resistive force acts to fluid particles, and thus, fluid velocities reduce. Impact of reciprocal magnetic Prandtl number l 1 on f' (z ) and g' (z ) are sketched in Figures 9-10. Here, when A < 1, both velocity and induced magnetic field (f' (z ) and g' (z )) are increased by l 1, and when A > 1, the result are reverse. Figure 11 plotted the impact of mixed convective
Figure 8. g' (z ) via b
Figure 9. f' (z ) via l 1
Figure 10. g' (z ) via l 1
parameter l on f' (z ). From these figures, it is observed that f' (z ) are enhanced via higher estimation of l for A < 1 and also for A > 1. It is because mixed convection parameter involves buoyancy forces which increases the liquid velocity.
Figures 12-21 are displayed to examine the impacts of (f 2), (b ), (l 1), (b 1) and (R) on the temperature of nanoliquid and hybrid nanoliquid. Here, three different class of nanoparticles (bricks, cylinders and platelets) are used. The shape factors are 3.7, 4.9 and 5.7.
Figures 12-13 represent the behavior of volumetric fractions (f 2) on temperature u (z ) for both nanoliquids (Cu-water) and hybrid nanoliquids (TiO2–Cu-water). Clearly, from these figures, the highest temperature is observed when the fluids are hybrid nanoliquids (TiO2– Cu-water) and the nanoparticles are platelets shape. Thermal conductivity nanoparticles enhances by selecting (TiO2–Cu-water and platelets shape of nanoparticle) when compared to nanoliquids (Cu-water) and other two classes of nanoparticles shapes. Figures 14-15
Figure 12. u (z ) via f 2
Figure 13. u (z ) via f 2
Figure 14. u (z ) via b
Figure 11. f' (z ) via l
HFF 29,8
2764
disclosed the behavior of (l 1) on temperature u (z ) of nanoliquid (Cu-water) and hybrid nanoliquid (TiO2–Cu-water). It is shown that temperature enhances via l 1 for both fluid. Higher temperature is observed when the fluids are hybrid nanoliquids (TiO2–Cu-water) and the nanoparticles of platelets shape. Physically the reciprocal magnetic Prandtl number is the ratio of viscous diffusion rate to magnetic diffusion rate. Physical higher value
corresponds to lower magnetic diffusion rate which consequently increases the nanoliquid temperature. Behavior of magnetic parameter (b ) on u (z ) of (Cu-water) and (TiO2–Cuwater) are investigated in Figures 16-17. It is shown that temperature decays with (b ); such change is greater for hybrid nanoliquids than nanoliquids. Magnetic parameter depends upon the Lorentz force. Hence, the Lorentz force resists the flow that enhances the temperature. Figures 18-19 sketched the effect of heat source (b 1) on temperature of nanoliquids and hybrid nanoliquids. We observed that u (z ) increases through changes in (b 1) for both kinds of fluids. The heat source occurrence contributes additional heat to the liquid that causes a rise in the temperature. Again the changes are smaller for nanoliquids when compared to hybrid nanoliquids. Impact of radiation parameter (R) on nanoliquids and hybrid nanoliquids are investigated in Figures 20-21. Here, u (z ) is enhanced through (R) of two types of fluids (nanoliquids and hybrid nanoliquids). Further changes are smaller for nanoliquids when compared to hybrid nanoliquids. Physically, the mean absorption
Figure 20. u (z ) via R
Figure 21. u (z ) via R
Figure 23. Cfx via l 1
Figure 22. Cfx via f 2
HFF 29,8
2766
coefficient is reduced for larger R which causes the radiation amount of heat transfer to liquid rise. Therefore, temperature increases.
Figures 22-30 highlighted the behaviors of (f 2), (b ), (l 1), (l ), (R) and u w on Cfx andNux. From these figures, we observed that Cfx for nanoliquids (Cu-water) is greater than hybrid nanoliquids (TiO2–Cu-water). Also, we observed that Nux for nanoliquids (Cu-water) is less thanNux hybrid nanoliquids (TiO2–Cu-water).
Tables IV and V show the comparison between the present results of surface drag force and heat transfer rate with the result of previously published study of Ghadikolaei et al. (2017) andMabood et al. (2016) for special cases. From these tables, it is clearly noticed that a good agreement between them.
Figure 26. Nux via f 2
Figure 27. Nux via l 1
Tables VI and VII show the behaviors of (f 2), (b ), (l ), (R), (u w) and (l 1) on local skin friction coefficient Cfx and Nusselt number Nux for nanoliquids (Cu-water) and hybrid nanoliquids (TiO2–Cu-water) for different shapes nanoparticles (bricks, cylinders and platelets). From these tables, we observe that for both fluids, that is, (Cu-water andTiO2–Cuwater); the parameters (f 2) (l 1), (b ), (R) and (u w) have a direct relation with Cf but (l ) have a contrast relation with Cfx . Clearly, Nux is an increasing function of (f 2), (l ), (R) and (u w) and it diminishes with (b ) and (l 1). Here, we concluded that nanoparticles having platelets shape is more efficient.

sections.heading: 7. Main points
sections.text:
Here, we discussed the impact of induced magnetic field on mixed convective stagnation flow ofTiO2–Cu/water hybrid nanofluid over a stretchable sheet. The key observations are:
When A < 1, the result of f' (z ) and g' (z ) for nanoliquid are less than hybrid nanoliquid and situation holds reverse for A> 1.
f' (z ) and g' (z ) are enhanced for large estimation of mixed convective parameter (l ) and reciprocal magnetic Prandtl number (l 1), while these decays for volumetric friction and magnetic parameter for both nanoliquid and hybrid nanoliquid whenA< 1.
f' (z ) and g' (z ) are increased for higher estimations of volumetric friction and (l ) n, while these diminished via magnetic parameter and reciprocal magnetic Prandtl number for both nanoliquid and hybrid nanoliquid when A> 1. Table V.

Mixed convective non-linear radiative flow

Temperature u (z ) enhances for larger estimation of (f 2), (b ), (l 1), (b 1) and (R) in hybrid nanoliquid and platelets-shaped nanoparticles.
Cf is an increasing function of (f 2) and (l 1) for both Cu-water and TiO2–Cu-water, while it decays via (b ) for both Cu-water and TiO2–Cu-water.
Nux enhances via (f 2) and (b ) and it decreases for (l 1) for both Cu-water and TiO2–Cu-water.
Cf for nanoliquids (Cu-water) is greater than hybrid nanoliquids (TiO2–Cu-water). Nux for nanoliquids (Cu-water) is less than hybrid nanoliquids (TiO2–Cu-water). Hybrid nanoliquids are more efficient than nanoliquids. Nanoparticles with platelets shape are more efficient.

referenceMentions.context: Thermal conductivity and heat transfer coefficient of base materials can be enhanced through the insertion of nanoparticles (Choi and Eastman, 1995; Buongiorno, 2006).
Thermal conductivity and heat transfer coefficient of base materials can be enhanced through the insertion of nanoparticles (Choi and Eastman, 1995; Buongiorno, 2006).

Thermal conductivity and heat transfer coefficient of base materials can be enhanced through the insertion of nanoparticles (Choi and Eastman, 1995; Buongiorno, 2006). The composition of solid particles containing 1-100 nm size in base materials are known as nanofluids. Such approach rises heat transportation in engineering utilization for illustration electronic mechanisms chilling equipped with nanofluids, food processing, energy stowing structures, heat exchangers and lubrication equipment. Choi and Eastman (1995) experimentally evaluated nanoliquids and discussed their contribution in base material along thermal conductivity improvement of the working material.

Thermal conductivity and heat transfer coefficient of base materials can be enhanced through the insertion of nanoparticles (Choi and Eastman, 1995; Buongiorno, 2006). The composition of solid particles containing 1-100 nm size in base materials are known as nanofluids. Such approach rises heat transportation in engineering utilization for illustration electronic mechanisms chilling equipped with nanofluids, food processing, energy stowing structures, heat exchangers and lubrication equipment. Choi and Eastman (1995) experimentally evaluated nanoliquids and discussed their contribution in base material along thermal conductivity improvement of the working material. Measuring thermal conductivity of ethylene glycol fluid through copper nano-particles was examined by Eastman et al. (2001). Impact of thermal radiation on magnetic nanofluid heat transfer into a curved cavity by CVFEM numerical method was studied by Sheikholeslami and Ganji (2017).

Thermal conductivity and heat transfer coefficient of base materials can be enhanced through the insertion of nanoparticles (Choi and Eastman, 1995; Buongiorno, 2006). The composition of solid particles containing 1-100 nm size in base materials are known as nanofluids. Such approach rises heat transportation in engineering utilization for illustration electronic mechanisms chilling equipped with nanofluids, food processing, energy stowing structures, heat exchangers and lubrication equipment. Choi and Eastman (1995) experimentally evaluated nanoliquids and discussed their contribution in base material along thermal conductivity improvement of the working material. Measuring thermal conductivity of ethylene glycol fluid through copper nano-particles was examined by Eastman et al. (2001). Impact of thermal radiation on magnetic nanofluid heat transfer into a curved cavity by CVFEM numerical method was studied by Sheikholeslami and Ganji (2017). Some investigations about nanofluids theory under various aspects are discussed in Qayyum et al.

Thermal conductivity and heat transfer coefficient of base materials can be enhanced through the insertion of nanoparticles (Choi and Eastman, 1995; Buongiorno, 2006). The composition of solid particles containing 1-100 nm size in base materials are known as nanofluids. Such approach rises heat transportation in engineering utilization for illustration electronic mechanisms chilling equipped with nanofluids, food processing, energy stowing structures, heat exchangers and lubrication equipment. Choi and Eastman (1995) experimentally evaluated nanoliquids and discussed their contribution in base material along thermal conductivity improvement of the working material. Measuring thermal conductivity of ethylene glycol fluid through copper nano-particles was examined by Eastman et al. (2001). Impact of thermal radiation on magnetic nanofluid heat transfer into a curved cavity by CVFEM numerical method was studied by Sheikholeslami and Ganji (2017). Some investigations about nanofluids theory under various aspects are discussed in Qayyum et al. (2017), Pandey and Kumar (2017), Mixed convective non-linear radiative flow
(2013), Ellahi et al. (2015), Hayat et al. (2018), Sheikholeslami et al. (2016) and Sheikholeslami and Ganji (2017).

(2013), Ellahi et al. (2015), Hayat et al. (2018), Sheikholeslami et al. (2016) and Sheikholeslami and Ganji (2017). Various studies have been elaborated about nanomaterials until now, but hybrid nanoliquid is a new type of fluids, which is of great interest to the present investigation.

(2013), Ellahi et al. (2015), Hayat et al. (2018), Sheikholeslami et al. (2016) and Sheikholeslami and Ganji (2017). Various studies have been elaborated about nanomaterials until now, but hybrid nanoliquid is a new type of fluids, which is of great interest to the present investigation. Hybrid nanofluid is the composite of two or more constituent at nanoparticles level within a base fluid and are used to improve the heat transfer features. Suresh et al. (2012) discussed the impact of laminar convective heat transfer in the tube using Al2O3-Cu/water hybrid nanofluid.

(2013), Ellahi et al. (2015), Hayat et al. (2018), Sheikholeslami et al. (2016) and Sheikholeslami and Ganji (2017). Various studies have been elaborated about nanomaterials until now, but hybrid nanoliquid is a new type of fluids, which is of great interest to the present investigation. Hybrid nanofluid is the composite of two or more constituent at nanoparticles level within a base fluid and are used to improve the heat transfer features. Suresh et al. (2012) discussed the impact of laminar convective heat transfer in the tube using Al2O3-Cu/water hybrid nanofluid. Here the improvement of gradient of temperature of hybrid nanoliquids compared to base fluid was noticed. Impact of turbulent convective heat transfer using Al2O3-Cu/water hybrid in circular tube was studied by Suresh et al. (2014). Here, we observed that heat transfer of hybrid nanofluids is 8.

(2013), Ellahi et al. (2015), Hayat et al. (2018), Sheikholeslami et al. (2016) and Sheikholeslami and Ganji (2017). Various studies have been elaborated about nanomaterials until now, but hybrid nanoliquid is a new type of fluids, which is of great interest to the present investigation. Hybrid nanofluid is the composite of two or more constituent at nanoparticles level within a base fluid and are used to improve the heat transfer features. Suresh et al. (2012) discussed the impact of laminar convective heat transfer in the tube using Al2O3-Cu/water hybrid nanofluid. Here the improvement of gradient of temperature of hybrid nanoliquids compared to base fluid was noticed. Impact of turbulent convective heat transfer using Al2O3-Cu/water hybrid in circular tube was studied by Suresh et al. (2014). Here, we observed that heat transfer of hybrid nanofluids is 8.02 per cent enhanced than that of water-based fluid. Nasrin and Alim (2014) discussed thermal effects of applications of (alumina and copper) double nanoparticles and (alumina) single nano-particle in the waterbased fluid for forced convection by a flat plate solar collector.

(2013), Ellahi et al. (2015), Hayat et al. (2018), Sheikholeslami et al. (2016) and Sheikholeslami and Ganji (2017). Various studies have been elaborated about nanomaterials until now, but hybrid nanoliquid is a new type of fluids, which is of great interest to the present investigation. Hybrid nanofluid is the composite of two or more constituent at nanoparticles level within a base fluid and are used to improve the heat transfer features. Suresh et al. (2012) discussed the impact of laminar convective heat transfer in the tube using Al2O3-Cu/water hybrid nanofluid. Here the improvement of gradient of temperature of hybrid nanoliquids compared to base fluid was noticed. Impact of turbulent convective heat transfer using Al2O3-Cu/water hybrid in circular tube was studied by Suresh et al. (2014). Here, we observed that heat transfer of hybrid nanofluids is 8.02 per cent enhanced than that of water-based fluid. Nasrin and Alim (2014) discussed thermal effects of applications of (alumina and copper) double nanoparticles and (alumina) single nano-particle in the waterbased fluid for forced convection by a flat plate solar collector. Their result proved that double nanoparticles had better activity than a single nanoparticle. Rostamian et al. (2017) experimentally showed that the impact of solid volume fraction changes temperature and thermal conductivity of CuO – SWCNTs – EG water.

(2013), Ellahi et al. (2015), Hayat et al. (2018), Sheikholeslami et al. (2016) and Sheikholeslami and Ganji (2017). Various studies have been elaborated about nanomaterials until now, but hybrid nanoliquid is a new type of fluids, which is of great interest to the present investigation. Hybrid nanofluid is the composite of two or more constituent at nanoparticles level within a base fluid and are used to improve the heat transfer features. Suresh et al. (2012) discussed the impact of laminar convective heat transfer in the tube using Al2O3-Cu/water hybrid nanofluid. Here the improvement of gradient of temperature of hybrid nanoliquids compared to base fluid was noticed. Impact of turbulent convective heat transfer using Al2O3-Cu/water hybrid in circular tube was studied by Suresh et al. (2014). Here, we observed that heat transfer of hybrid nanofluids is 8.02 per cent enhanced than that of water-based fluid. Nasrin and Alim (2014) discussed thermal effects of applications of (alumina and copper) double nanoparticles and (alumina) single nano-particle in the waterbased fluid for forced convection by a flat plate solar collector. Their result proved that double nanoparticles had better activity than a single nanoparticle. Rostamian et al. (2017) experimentally showed that the impact of solid volume fraction changes temperature and thermal conductivity of CuO – SWCNTs – EG water. They observed that temperature and solid volume fraction have direct relation with thermal conductivity. Convective flow of silver and copper water nanofluids with thermal radiation is discussed by Hayat et al. (2016). Peristaltic flow of viscoelastic nanoparticle with Hall and ion effects is examined by Hayat et al.

(2013), Ellahi et al. (2015), Hayat et al. (2018), Sheikholeslami et al. (2016) and Sheikholeslami and Ganji (2017). Various studies have been elaborated about nanomaterials until now, but hybrid nanoliquid is a new type of fluids, which is of great interest to the present investigation. Hybrid nanofluid is the composite of two or more constituent at nanoparticles level within a base fluid and are used to improve the heat transfer features. Suresh et al. (2012) discussed the impact of laminar convective heat transfer in the tube using Al2O3-Cu/water hybrid nanofluid. Here the improvement of gradient of temperature of hybrid nanoliquids compared to base fluid was noticed. Impact of turbulent convective heat transfer using Al2O3-Cu/water hybrid in circular tube was studied by Suresh et al. (2014). Here, we observed that heat transfer of hybrid nanofluids is 8.02 per cent enhanced than that of water-based fluid. Nasrin and Alim (2014) discussed thermal effects of applications of (alumina and copper) double nanoparticles and (alumina) single nano-particle in the waterbased fluid for forced convection by a flat plate solar collector. Their result proved that double nanoparticles had better activity than a single nanoparticle. Rostamian et al. (2017) experimentally showed that the impact of solid volume fraction changes temperature and thermal conductivity of CuO – SWCNTs – EG water. They observed that temperature and solid volume fraction have direct relation with thermal conductivity. Convective flow of silver and copper water nanofluids with thermal radiation is discussed by Hayat et al. (2016). Peristaltic flow of viscoelastic nanoparticle with Hall and ion effects is examined by Hayat et al. (2016). Shao et al. (2017) examined solidification behaviors of hybrid nanofluids containing TiNTs and TiNPs in 10 freeze-melt cycles.
Alfvén (1942) indicated the study of magnetohydrodynamic (MHD).

Alfvén (1942) indicated the study of magnetohydrodynamic (MHD). Entropy generation in Sisko fluid flow with non-linear thermal radiation and dissipation is presented by Hayat et al. (2018). Turkyilmazoglu (2018) discussed flow of nanomaterial by using Buongiorno model.

Alfvén (1942) indicated the study of magnetohydrodynamic (MHD). Entropy generation in Sisko fluid flow with non-linear thermal radiation and dissipation is presented by Hayat et al. (2018). Turkyilmazoglu (2018) discussed flow of nanomaterial by using Buongiorno model.

Alfvén (1942) indicated the study of magnetohydrodynamic (MHD). Entropy generation in Sisko fluid flow with non-linear thermal radiation and dissipation is presented by Hayat et al. (2018). Alfvén (1942) indicated the study of magnetohydrodynamic (MHD). Entropy generation in Sisko fluid flow with non-linear thermal radiation and dissipation is presented by Hayat et al. (2018). Alfvén (1942) indicated the study of magnetohydrodynamic (MHD). Entropy generation in Sisko fluid flow with non-linear thermal radiation and dissipation is presented by Hayat et al. (2018). Turkyilmazoglu (2018) discussed flow of nanomaterial by using Buongiorno model. Ali et al. (2011) examined the effects of induced magnetic field on MHD boundary layer flow of viscous fluid. Turkyilmazoglu (2017) scrutinized unsteady stagnation point flow of MHD viscous fluid. Kumar and Singh (2013) presented the influence of induced magnetic field on the unsteady hydromagnetic free convection over a semi-finite vertical wall. Impacts of MHD and slip velocity on the stagnation point flow of Jeffrey fluid is discussed by Turkyilmazoglu (2016). Pal and Mandal (2015) explored the impact of thermal radiation on mixed convective boundary layer stagnation point flow towards a stretching surface in porous medium. Some resent results about nanoliquids are presented in Mansor and Zaimi (2014), Mabood and Khan (2014), Hayat et al. (2018), Imtiaz et al. (2017), Khan et al. (2017), Qayyum et al. (2018) and Hayat et al. (2017). Having above view in mind, basic focus of current attempt is to explore non-linear stretched flow of hybrid nanofluid (TiO2 – Cu/water) in four dimensions: First, to model the analysis for induced magnetic field at (TiO2 – Cu/water) nanofluid; second, to study the thermophysical features of hybrid nanofluid for various values of shape factor; third, to address the characteristics of hybrid nanofluid in the region of mixed convective stagnation point; heat transport features are explored through thermal radiation and heat generation/ absorption; and fourth, to construct the series solutions via homotopy analysis method (HAM).

metadata.abstractText: Purpose – The purpose of this paper is to address the impact of induced magnetic field in mixed convective stagnation flow of TiO2-Cu-water hybrid nanofluid towards a stretchable sheet. Non-linear thermal radiation and heat source/sink are accounted. Flow of hybrid nanofluid is discussed. Non-linear partial differential expressions are converted to ordinary ones through appropriate transformations. Design/methodology/approach – The obtained systems are solved for convergence solutions via homotopy analysis method. Graphical results are discussed for different physical variables on the velocity, induced magnetic field and temperature fields for both Cu water nanofluid and TiO2-Cu-water hybrid nanofluid. Finally, the effect of different physical variables on skin friction coefficient (Cfx) and Nusselt numberNux in the presence of water nanofluid andTiO2-Cu-water hybrid nanofluid are discussed. Findings – Velocities and induced magnetic field are increasing functions of mixed convection parameter and nanoparticle volume fraction. Temperature rises for higher radiation parameter. Skin friction is greater in case of Cu-water nanoliquid, while Nusselt number is less for Cu-water nanofluid when they are compared with hybrid nanoliquidTiO2-Cu-water. Originality/value – No such work is not yet present in the literature.
